item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Lubrication of Platter Motor Bearings
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), the DC motor was lubricated. This particular motor uses brushes and has simple sleeve bearings. To access the bearings for lubrication, the pulley and outer housing were removed. The pulley is attached to the shaft with glue, allowing for easy removal. After taking out two small screws, the housing can be opened and the motor taken out. Next, the black rubber vibration insulation boot was removed, revealing the circuit board connected to the brushes.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of the DC Motor - Oil Infusion of Bearings, and Repair of a Broken Off Brush and a Disconnected Sensing Coil
item.description: I recently received a Beogram 4002 (5513) DC motor from the Netherlands. The motor was dead on arrival, so I opened it up and discovered a broken commutator spring that had been taped on with electrical tape. Unsurprisingly, the motor wouldn’t turn. I also found a broken lead on one of the sensing coils, which should have a resistance of 22 Ohms between the contact terminals. This break disabled the motor’s feedback mechanism.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Restoring the DC Platter Motor
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5523) restoration continued with a focus on the motor. The motor was noticeably loud, a common issue in DC 4002 models often caused by dried lubricant in the sleeve bearings. Addressing this requires disassembling the motor, cleaning it, and applying fresh lubricant. The first image highlights the upper sleeve bearing after the rotor was removed. The next image provides a view of the lower bearing, feedback coils, and brushes.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Infusing Oilite Brass Bearings of DC Motor with Oil Under Vacuum
item.description: Restoring the DC motors found in Beogram 4002/4 turntables (models 551x and 552x) presents a significant challenge. Many of these motors exhibit loud operation and inconsistent rotational speed due to their age. While lubricating the motor’s brass sleeve bearings with grease might seem like a solution, this often only yields temporary improvement. The root of the issue lies in the use of ‘oilite’ bearings, which are designed to operate without external lubrication.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor: Spark Snubber Replacement
item.description: I recently had a Beogram 4002 DC platter motor on my workbench that I had previously worked on in November 2016 due to a broken brush and a severed pickup coil lead. The motor recently began experiencing RPM fluctuations again. This pointed to a problem with the spark snubbers. To access the rotor, I opened the motor: The spark snubbers, marked with red dots, are located around the commutator. The replacements are on the black pad.

item.title: Beogram 4002: DC Motor Restoration and RPM Stability Test
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC motor from France was received for restoration. As is typical, the motor’s Oilite brass bearings needed fresh oil. This requires disassembling the motor and extracting the bearings for a vacuum oiling process. The bearings were submerged in motor oil under vacuum, forcing air out of the porous material and drawing oil in. This process generally takes about 24 hours. This shows the bearings after the oil infusion.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Restoration of DC Motor and a Dead TR2 Transistor
item.description: After refreshing the PCBs and the RPM trimmer scale backlighting on a Beogram 4002 (5523) turntable, I turned my attention to its DC motor. Most DC motors in these models need their Oilite brass bearings replenished with oil, as the oil tends to seep out over time, leading to RPM instability. To do this, the motor needs to be disassembled. The bearings sit on a black pad within the motor. I noticed the motor had been previously repaired, evident in the bent brushes, which would have hindered its performance.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Oil Infusion of DC Platter Motor Bearings and RPM Test
item.description: To fully rebuild the platter drive system of a Beogram 4002 DC motor, you must relubricate the motor bearings. Many DC motor Beograms have fluctuating RPMs because the oil in their porous brass bearings (called “Oilite”) depletes over time. These bearings can be ‘refilled’ by using a vacuum to remove air and allow oil to replenish the pores. The challenge lies in extracting the bearings without causing damage. I documented this process in a recent video.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Exciting DC Motor Failure Mode Due to a Shorted Spark Snubber
item.description: Another Beogram 4002 (5513) DC motor in need of repair recently came to my workbench. During my standard pre-restoration test using a Beogram 4002, this motor was unusually sluggish, only operating with assistance. This contrasted with the typical DC motors I encounter, which generally run powerfully but exhibit RPM fluctuations and often produce high-pitched sounds due to dried-out bearings. This particular motor was noticeably underpowered. I disassembled the motor and performed my usual bearing oil infusion to ensure the mechanical components were within specifications before addressing the sluggishness.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513 - DC Motor, Main PCB and RPM Panel Restoration
item.description: A Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable from Arizona was received for restoration, exhibiting the common issue of RPM fluctuations. To address this, the motor was prioritized, as revitalizing dry bearings with oil is a time-consuming process. The motor was disassembled to access the bearings. These were then submerged in motor oil within a vacuum environment. This process, characterized by vigorous bubbling, facilitates the oil’s penetration into the bearings’ porous material by drawing out trapped air.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Platter Motor: Replacement of Spark Snubbers
item.description: A Beogram 4002 (5513) DC platter motor, previously restored in 2016, displayed RPM fluctuations and required attention. Although the motor’s bearings had been treated with oil at that time, the spark snubbers were not replaced. The motor had functioned correctly following the initial restoration. Initial testing involved installing the motor in a 4002 turntable and monitoring its RPM stability over 24 hours. The results are represented by the blue line in the provided graph.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Restoration of DC Platter Motor, PCBs and RPM Panel
item.description: I recently obtained the DC platter motor, circuit boards, and RPM panel from a Beogram 4002 (5513) located in California. I began with the motor, as is customary, because it requires a few days for the oil to fully permeate the bearings. To begin, I took the motor apart to access the bearings. Then, I submerged the bearings in motor oil and created a vacuum. This process helps to remove air from the bearing material, allowing the oil to penetrate more effectively.

item.title: Beogram 4002: DC Motor Restoration and Dependence of RPM Performance on the Value of C10
item.description: I recently obtained two DC motors from Beogram 4002 turntables that are being refurbished. One of the motors is pictured here. The first step in restoring these motors is addressing the brass sleeve bearings, which are often dry after more than 35 years of use. I do this through an oil infusion process, which requires complete disassembly, as shown. The bearings, visible on the black pad in the front, are submerged in oil and placed under vacuum.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): DC Motor Restoration and Yet Another Exciting Aspect of Achieving RPM Stability
item.description: To restore the platter drive system of a Beogram 4002 (5513) DC motor, several upgrades are necessary. These include installing modern multi-turn RPM trimmers, a new RPM relay, replacing the RPM trimmer backlights with LEDs, and refreshing the motor bearings with oil. Testing the RPM stability after each step reveals their individual impact on performance. This particular Beogram 4002 had already undergone most of these improvements, with the exception of the motor restoration.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: A New Tool on the Bench and the Importance of the Orientation of the Top Bearing
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC platter motor was acquired for restoration. Evidence suggested prior repair attempts on the motor, including scratches on the bearing assembly and damaged brushes. Upon disassembly, it was clear the bearings hadn’t been properly oiled. A vacuum oil infusion process was conducted on both the top and bottom bearings. After cleaning and reassembly, a short circuit was detected, pointing to faulty spark snubbers. The old spark snubbers were replaced with modern TVS devices.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration - Oil Infusion, New Spark Snubbers and an Ultrasonic Cleaning
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC platter motor was recently sent in for repair. Initial testing showed the motor was barely functional. To address this, the motor was disassembled, and the bearings were removed for lubrication. The bearings, designed to be porous and oil-filled, were treated with a vacuum oil infusion process. This process, evidenced by vigorous bubbling, helps to replenish the oil within the bearings over time. After a few days, the bubbling subsided, indicating the bearings were adequately filled with oil, and they were removed from the oil bath.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration - Oil Infusion of Bearings and New Spark Snubbers
item.description: A DC motor, removed from a Beogram 4002 in Arlington, VA, was sent in for repair. The initial step involved taking the motor apart and extracting its bearings for lubrication. The bearings, resembling small rings, were submerged in motor oil and a vacuum was applied. This process causes air bubbles to emerge from the bearing material, indicating oil infusion. After a day, the bubbling stopped, signifying that the bearings were saturated with oil.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the DC Motor and a Significant Improvement of the RPM Stability
item.description: A recently acquired Beogram 4002 turntable exhibited significant speed variations during an initial performance test. The frequent and irregular drops in rotations per minute (RPM) pointed to a need for cleaning and lubrication of the DC motor. The motor was removed from its housing for servicing. The motor was then disassembled to allow for cleaning and lubrication of its bearings. Following reassembly and reinstallation of the motor, a 24-hour RPM test was conducted.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5524): Infusing the DC Motor Oilite Bearings with Fresh Oil
item.description: Following the PCB restoration of the Beogram 4002 (5524), the DC motor required attention. The Oilite brass bearings, designed with a ’lifetime’ lubricant within their pores, typically need replenishing after approximately four decades. This involves submerging the bearings in motor oil and using a vacuum to extract air from the pores, allowing oil to penetrate. A detailed video demonstrating this process is available here. Here’s a glimpse at this specific motor, both extracted from the turntable:

item.title: Beogram 4002: Restoration of DC Motor Video Published - Check It Out!
item.description: I’ve finished my Beogram DC motor restoration video due to high demand! This video will show you how to disassemble the motor and revitalize the Oilite brass bearings by infusing oil under a vacuum. If your Beogram’s RPM is inconsistent, this video is for you! Have a look:

item.title: Beogram 4002: Restoration of a Very Oily DC Platter Motor
item.description: I obtained a Beogram 4002 DC platter motor from Berlin, Germany, for restoration. The motor’s exterior was noticeably oily, likely due to an attempt to improve its RPM stability through lubrication. Disassembly was necessary to access and treat the bearings. The motor’s interior was also oil-coated. However, this is ineffective for the bearings, as they require vacuum oil infusion. This process removes air trapped within the porous Oilite brass material, enabling new oil to penetrate the bearing effectively.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Platter Motor Restoration
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC platter motor, sent from Pennsylvania for repair, showed typical signs of needing lubrication, emitting a high-pitched noise when first turned on. The motor was taken apart to access the bearings for oil treatment. The bearings were placed in oil and a vacuum was applied. The appearance of bubbles showed air being pulled from the bearings, making room for oil to enter. After two days, the bubbles ceased, signaling the completion of the oil infusion process.

item.title: Another Surprise Addition To The Workshop Beogram 4004
item.description: In 2021, I refurbished my Beogram 4004 turntable, which I call the “Workshop Beogram 4004”. Later that year, I added the Beolover Remote Commander and have enjoyed using it to play records. This year, I made another enhancement to my Beogram 4004: a Beolover SyncDrive Platter Motor. I was eager to try it out after reading about it on the Beolover Blog. My Beogram 4004 was already restored and in regular use, with a perfectly functional DC platter motor restored by Beolover in 2021.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): More RPM Measurements
item.description: Following up on the Beogram 4002 (5513) from the previous day, I conducted an overnight RPM (revolutions per minute) performance test using my BeoloverRPM device. The resulting measurement curve demonstrates excellent performance, typical of DC motor models. It shows minimal fluctuations (less than 0.05%) over time, aligning with the service manual’s specifications. The initial upward slope, lasting a couple of hours, is a common trait in the 551x and 552x models.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Platter Motor and Main PCB
item.description: I recently obtained a main PCB and DC platter motor from a Beogram 4002. I began with the motor refurbishment, a process that often requires several days for the bearings to become saturated with oil. The motor is depicted here: Disassembly was necessary to access the bearings, visible as two small rings on the black component in the front: The motor’s interior was noticeably oily, suggesting prior tampering. This was supported by a damaged commutator brush that was bent out of its intended form:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Motor: A New Tool and a New Spark Suppressor
item.description: I worked on restoring a Beogram 4002 DC motor, a process that unveiled a new and interesting failure point for these motors. This experience further refines the restoration process for these motors. The motor needed its usual oil infusion for the porous brass bearings. The motor’s rough operation when powered confirmed this need. Upon disassembly, I found this motor had the older brush carrier design, notorious for being glued to the alignment posts and feedback coils.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Restoration of DC Platter Motor
item.description: I obtained a Beogram 4002 DC platter motor from the Netherlands, but couldn’t use it. The top bearing suspension was damaged beyond repair. As a result, I refurbished a different motor I had on hand. To lubricate the bearings, I took the motor apart and submerged them in oil. A vacuum was applied to the oil-submerged bearings. This caused significant bubbling, signifying air escaping from the bearing material and creating space for oil to enter.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Initial RPM Performance Characterization
item.description: This post follows up on my initial writing about the Beogram 4002 (5513). I used my recently created BeoloverRPM device to assess the unit’s RPM performance. This test clearly showed the suspected rapid speed changes. The graph below displays the RPM over a roughly 24-hour period. The abrupt negative spikes in the graph indicate that the DC motor and its control system require attention.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding DC Motor with Oil Infused Oilite Bearings
item.description: Following the replacement of the RPM relay and trimmers in the Beogram 4002 (5513) with updated parts, the DC motor required attention. The DC motor often proves to be the most challenging aspect of restoring a 4002 and nearly always demands attention. The primary hurdle lies in restoring the motor’s Oilite oil-infused brass sleeve bearings. These bearings are “pre-lubricated” in a new motor. From a typical consumer perspective, with a lifespan of 10-15 years, these bearings might be considered “maintenance-free.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Comparison of the RPM Stability Between Four Motors
item.description: Sonavor is currently restoring four Beogram 4002 turntables and recently asked for assistance in refurbishing the DC motors. The restoration process involves removing the motor bearings, cleaning them, and applying fresh oil. To ensure effectiveness, a vacuum is used to draw the oil into the porous bearing material. The bearings are then cleaned of excess oil and reinstalled. After reassembly, each motor undergoes a 24-hour RPM stability test using a specialized device.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): Rebuilding a Noisy DC Motor with Oil Infused Bearings
item.description: The majority of Beogram 4002 turntables equipped with a DC motor require motor refurbishment. Indicators of this need include abrupt drops in revolutions per minute (RPM) or audible motor noise during operation. This specific Beogram 4002 (5514) exhibited significant noise during unloaded operation. As part of my restoration process for all 4002 turntables, I comprehensively rebuild the DC motors to preemptively address these common issues. The primary contributor to these performance issues lies in the brass sleeve bearings.

item.title: Beogram 4002 551x: Exciting!! Replica DC Motor Bearing Prototypes from Beoparts Successfully Tested
item.description: I received another set of Beogram 4002 platter motor components and an RPM panel from a customer in the Netherlands to restore. My work started with the motor, as it usually does. I disassembled the motor to get to the bearings. Typically, I would show a picture of the bearings being oiled in a vacuum chamber, but I received new Oilite bearings from www.beoparts-shop.com specifically for these DC motors, which I am testing.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Restoration of DC Motor - Oil Infusion of the Bearings and Installation of New Spark Snubbers
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC motor arrived from New Zealand for restoration. The upside-down pulley suggested prior repairs. Disassembly revealed a bent brush, a possible cause for the motor’s poor performance. [Image of motor with bent brush] The motor was fully disassembled, and the bearings underwent an oil infusion process to address potential RPM instability, a common issue. [Image of disassembled motor] [Image of bearings in oil] After the infusion, the bent brush was straightened.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of the DC Motor - Oil Infusion of the Oilite Bearings
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, the DC motor required attention. The bearings were making noise, indicating a need for lubrication. This is a common issue in Beogram DC motors of this age, often requiring oil replenishment for stable performance. The motor was removed from the turntable for servicing. The bearings, identified as two ring-shaped components, were taken out of the motor. To lubricate them, the bearings were submerged in motor oil, and a vacuum was applied to remove trapped air.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): DC Motor Restoration
item.description: I recently restored a DC motor from a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable. The turntable exhibited the common issue of inconsistent RPM, indicating the need to lubricate the motor bearings. I documented this process in detail in a video posted earlier. Here are some observations from the motor restoration. The first image shows the motor in its initial condition upon arrival: This image shows the motor after disassembly: The two small “donut” shapes in the front right of the photo are the bearings.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Oil Infusion of Bearings, Replacement of Spark Snubbers, and Repair of a Disconnected Pickup Coil
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC motor arrived from Michigan. Initial inspection showed no obvious external issues. However, a bench test revealed the rotor was blocked, preventing the motor from spinning. Upon disassembly, it was evident that someone had previously attempted a repair: the brushes were deformed and a pickup coil pin was broken. Further disassembly revealed a loose and disconnected coil near the missing pin. To address potential bearing issues, the bearings were submerged in motor oil and a vacuum was applied.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Platter Motor: Some Microsurgery on Disconnected Pickup Coils
item.description: I recently obtained a DC platter motor from a Beogram 4002 located in Norway. The motor required repair. The owner had already performed the ‘oil infusion’ procedure for the Oilite bearings. However, after reassembling and reinstalling the motor into the Beogram, the platter’s speed was excessively high and could not be adjusted. This image displays the motor, without the pulley, in the condition I received it: Uncontrollably high speed in a DC platter motor usually indicates a problem with one or both of the RPM feedback pickup coils within the motor, assuming the motor control circuit is functioning correctly.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Platter Motor, Main PCB and RPM Adjustment Panel
item.description: A Beogram 4002 turntable, experiencing RPM fluctuations, recently arrived from a customer for repair. The restoration process involved addressing issues with the DC platter motor, the main PCB, and the RPM adjustment panel. The platter motor was disassembled to lubricate the bearings. After immersing them in oil and applying a vacuum, the bearings were left undisturbed for two days to ensure proper saturation. Once the bubbling ceased, indicating full replenishment, the bearings were extracted and the motor was reassembled.

item.title: Beogram 4002 and 4004 DC Motor Restoration
item.description: I recently acquired two DC motors from Beogram 4002 and 4004 turntables located in Denmark. My typical first step is an oil infusion process to address RPM fluctuations, a common issue. The 4002 motor arrived in this condition: Disassembly revealed the following: The two small, donut-shaped brass bearings, visible on the black pad, were submerged in motor oil under a vacuum. Bubbles appeared immediately, indicating the oil infusion process was working.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Repair of a Damaged Pickup Coil and Oil Infusion
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC platter motor from Australia was sent in for repair. The owner reported the motor always ran at high speed, suggesting a broken RPM feedback coil. Without this feedback, the motor receives maximum power and spins as fast as possible. Disassembly revealed the motor’s brushes were improperly installed and a solder burn marked one terminal. The small pickup coils, responsible for sending an AC voltage proportional to motor RPM, were also examined.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): RPM Performance Measurement after Restoration of DC Motor and Control System
item.description: Following the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5514) turntable’s DC motor and control system, a 24-hour RPM performance test was conducted using a custom-built RPM monitoring device. The initial performance, measured before the restoration, revealed noticeable, abrupt drops in RPM, indicating typical wear and tear in the DC motor’s brass sleeve bearings. These dips, while moderate in this instance, would have been audible due to their 1% magnitude. After the restoration, which included rebuilding the motor and replacing RPM-related components, the significant RPM fluctuations were eliminated.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration - The Influence of C10 on RPM Stability
item.description: Another Beogram 4002 DC motor was prepped for restoration. The process began by removing the bearings for an oil infusion. The small brass bearings were submerged in motor oil, and a vacuum was applied. Bubbling indicated that the oil was being drawn into the bearings. These bearings took longer than usual, approximately 48 hours, for the bubbling to cease. After the bubbling stopped, the bearings were taken out of the oil

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Oil Infusion of the Bearings and a Shiny New Pulley from Austria
item.description: Another Beogram 4002 DC platter motor in need of repair came to my workshop from Virginia. Here’s a picture of the motor: The motor’s pulley was unusually worn, with a groove where the raised center, designed to keep the belt aligned, should be: It barely functioned during the initial test. To address this, I disassembled it to lubricate the bearings: The bearings are the two small rings on the black surface.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration
item.description: I recently obtained a Beogram 4002 DC motor from France that needed some repair. My typical first step is to rejuvenate the oil-impregnated brass bearings by submerging them in oil. This process is usually successful in restoring motor function. This image displays the motor in its initial condition upon arrival: To access the bearings, I took the motor apart: The bearings are the two small ring-shaped components on the black surface.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Oil Infusion of Bearings and Installation of New Spark Snubbers
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC motor, in need of restoration, arrived from Washington state. Initial examination showed it needed some work. A bench test confirmed the bearings were squeaking, a common issue. The motor was disassembled to remove the bearings for lubrication. The bearings were placed in motor oil under a vacuum. This process forces air out of the bearing material and allows oil to penetrate it. After a few days, the bearings were removed from the oil.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Platter Motor Bearings with Oil Infusion Under Vacuum
item.description: I’m working on restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable and decided to address the DC motor while it’s open. Previously, I hadn’t realized the importance of properly lubricating the motor bearings for long-term stability. Simply applying grease provided a temporary fix, but RPM fluctuations would reappear after a few weeks. This time, I completely disassembled the motor to access the bearings. To ensure proper lubrication, I used a vacuum method with a mason jar and a FoodSaver pump.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoring the DC Motor
item.description: Following the reconstruction of the Beogram 4002 (5513)’s arm lowering and tracking mechanisms, I shifted my focus to the electronics, starting with the motor. While the turntable’s RPM stability was excellent, I believe a thorough restoration involves servicing every part, including the motor, to ensure long-term reliability and everyday usability. The initial step involved extracting the motor from its housing: Next, I removed the motor from its noise shield: and proceeded to disassemble it:
